pullRequest.body:
This PR creates config options for `fail_if_no_progress` that allow the user to tweak what exactly counts as "progress". This includes whether to use defeq or `BEq`, what transparency to use, and which parts of the goal and local context to check.

It also splits off the comparison functionality into `Mathlib.Lean.Meta.Compare`, which provides fully configurable comparison functions for common complex metaprogramming types not specific to `fail_if_no_progress`. These types are `Expr`, `LocalDecl`, `LocalContext`, `MetavarDecl`, `MVarId`, and `List MVarId`.

---
See [zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/progress.20on.20fail_if_no_progress) for a couple review questions.

Status update: this PR is now basically done, save for some extra tests which should probably be included.

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: @thorimur what's the status of this, is there anything I can do to help move it forward?
lgtm :)

Very solid and highly configurable `fail_if_no_progress`. The tactic part is quite concise, most of `FailIfNoProgress.lean` are highly detailed doc-strings.

`Compare.lean` builds up the configuration options in a layered way. I can't comment on whether these are all possible things one could possibly want to compare, but it looks pretty extensive. Default's seem reasonable, but can't really judge that either.

I hope these comments help getting this PR going :)
lgtm :)

```suggestion
`MVarId`s and `FVarId`s are ignored by default, as are implementation details like `ldecls` in the local
```

Actually I think this was just a stray `l` (`ldecls` *are* included by default)—but we don't really need to specify that implementation details are `decls` anyway!
```suggestion
`MVarId`s and `FVarId`s are ignored by default, as are implementation details in the local
```

```suggestion
* Configs to tweak list comparisons: `canLose`, `canGain`, `orderless`
```

```suggestion
is used to determine equality as described. If `mode := .quick`, the rest of the config is
```

```suggestion
* `mode := .normal` – If `mode := .normal`, the rest of the config is used to determine equality
```

```suggestion
  -- If progress was made, we return `l`
  if let .quick := cfg.mode then
    if ← goal.isAssigned then return l
  else
    let [newGoal] := l | return l
    if (← goal.compare newGoal cfg.toMVarIdComparisonConfig
      cfg.toExprComparisonConfig decl) then return l
  -- No progress made
```
would it the same this way around? Is there a reason to use a wildcard `catch _ => `?

Ah, yeah, I think this was a holdover from some older control flow—or I just wrote it convolutedly to begin with. :) However, note that `compare` is `true` when they're the same, and if they're the same, no progress has been made—so we actually want `unless` here.
```suggestion
  -- If progress was made, we return `l`
  if let .quick := cfg.mode then
    if ← goal.isAssigned then return l
  else
    let [newGoal] := l | return l
    unless (← goal.compare newGoal cfg.toMVarIdComparisonConfig cfg.toExprComparisonConfig decl) do 
      return l
  -- We reach here only if no progress was made
```

```suggestion
def failIfNoProgress (tacs : TacticM α) (cfg : FailIfNoProgress.Config := {}) : TacticM α := do
```
I think the `mathlib` convention is to not have the cases of a `match` statement indented.

Hmm, I was curious, and it seems both conventions are used in the case of `let a ← match b with`. My reasoning was that the indentation of the whole term following `←` is one tab greater than that of the `let`. (E.g. if a function's arguments spilled over to the next line, we'd indent them by one tab.) So, by indenting one tab, I'm keeping the `|`'s aligned with the `match`'s indentation (instead of the `let`s). Likewise, consider what happens when `a` becomes longer:
```
let x ← match a with
  | _ => ...

let x ←
  match aaaaaaaaaaaaaaa with
  | _ => ...
```
But maybe that's not how it should work! I'm open to changing it. :)
You might be right, and in any case there isn't really a convention written down yet.
I wonder if "no goals closed" (or "solved"?) or something would be better for the average user than using "assigned", even if the latter is technically correct?

My choice of `assigned` here was to emphasize the fact that often metavariables get assigned to other only-slightly-different metavariables—so, sometimes a goal gets assigned even if it doesn't look "solved" or "closed". But maybe this doesn't help alleviate that potential confusion...I'll think about it a little. :)
I understand! In that case "closed/solved" would be misleading!

```suggestion
```
The mathlib convention is probably to not have these spaces, isn't it?

There's certainly precedent for using spaces to align *lots* of fields/definitions vertically, but you're right, probably not for just two—and not along `:` :)
```suggestion
  eqKind : EqKind := .defEq
```

Everywhere from here on (and in `FailIfNoProgress.lean`) you always use the two configs together:
```
(cfg : LocalDeclComparisonConfig := {}) (ecfg : ExprComparisonConfig)
```
I wonder if it would make sense to bundle `ExprComparisonConfig` already in `LocalDeclComparisonConfig` to avoid always having two arguments everywhere or if there is any particular reason one would not want that.

There was a reason for this—I think. I really ought to have documented it at the time. :) I'll try to remind myself about it tomorrow when I'm feeling a bit more refreshed and/or refactor if it's unnecessary.

Ah, right. The reason was that we use the following pattern for specifying e.g. the `LocalContextComparisonConfig` in the `MetavarDeclComparisonConfig`:
```
structure MetavarDeclComparisonConfig where
  ...
  compareLocalContexts? : Option LocalContextComparisonConfig := some {}
```
If we don't want to compare the local contexts at all, we set this to `none`.

If `LocalContextComparisonConfig` extended `ExprComparisonConfig`, then its default values would be different than the "global" values. This would cause unexpected behavior: you set `.eqKind := `.isDefEq` at the top level, but don't wind up using `.isDefEq` on the local context!

We could get around this in two other ways if we wanted to:
1. by having `LocalContextComparisonConfig` take in a parameter of type `ExprComparisonConfig` which was set by other fields of `MetavarDeclComparisonConfig` and only existed to propagate the "global" defaults in from `MetavarDeclComparisonConfig`. This was advised against [here](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/270676-lean4/topic/Inheriting.20defaults.20from.20parent.20structures).
2. by using a different pattern: have a field `checkLocalContext : Bool` in `MetavarDeclComparisonConfig` which toggled whether the comparison happened, and having `MetavarDeclComparisonConfig` extend `LocalContextComparisonConfig`. I thought this might be a little more error-prone, as then you'd still have all the `LocalContextComparisonConfig` fields floating around even when they weren't being used at all. By using an `Option` we prevent this data from even existing when it's not relevant.

I'll add the explanation to the module doc, unless we want to change the way it works. :)
Thanks for the explanation! I think that's a good argument to leave it as it!

```suggestion
    (cfg : LocalContextComparisonConfig := {}) (ecfg : ExprComparisonConfig := {}) : MetaM Bool := do
```

```suggestion
    (ecfg : ExprComparisonConfig := {}) : MetaM Bool :=
```

```suggestion
def LocalContext.compare (lctx₁ lctx₂ : LocalContext) (cfg : LocalContextComparisonConfig := {})
    (ecfg : ExprComparisonConfig := {}) : MetaM Bool := do
```

````suggestion

## Implementation notes

We use the following pattern for specifying e.g. the `LocalContextComparisonConfig` in the `MetavarDeclComparisonConfig`:
```
structure MetavarDeclComparisonConfig where
  ...
  compareLocalContexts? : Option LocalContextComparisonConfig := some {}
```
If `compareLocalContexts?` is `none`, we don't compare local contexts at all.

However, this pattern means that the config for comparing `Expr`s, which is needed both when comparing `LocalContext`s and `MetavarDecl`s, can't simply be extended by `LocalContextComparisonConfig`, as that's not always present in `MetavarDeclComparisonConfig`. It also can't simply be extended by *both* `LocalContextComparisonConfig` and `MetavarDeclComparisonConfig` (using this pattern), as then changing the setting in `MetavarDeclComparisonConfig` wouldn't propagate that setting down into `LocalContextComparisonConfig`.

As such, we also pass `ExprComparisonConfig` as an argument to each `compare` function.

````

````suggestion
## Implementation notes

We use the following pattern for specifying e.g. the `LocalContextComparisonConfig` in the 
`MetavarDeclComparisonConfig`:
```
structure MetavarDeclComparisonConfig where
  ...
  compareLocalContexts? : Option LocalContextComparisonConfig := some {}
```
If `compareLocalContexts?` is `none`, we don't compare local contexts at all.

However, this pattern means that the config for comparing `Expr`s, which is needed both when 
comparing `LocalContext`s and `MetavarDecl`s, can't simply be extended by 
`LocalContextComparisonConfig`, as that's not always present in `MetavarDeclComparisonConfig`. It 
also can't simply be extended by *both* `LocalContextComparisonConfig` and 
`MetavarDeclComparisonConfig` (using this pattern), as then changing the setting in 
`MetavarDeclComparisonConfig` wouldn't propagate that setting down into 
`LocalContextComparisonConfig`.

As such, we also pass `ExprComparisonConfig` as an argument to each `compare` function.
````
I can't make sense of this sentence.
Rewritten. :)
There's no longer a `ListM`, which was renamed `MLList`.

This seems a weird type signature. Perhaps that return type should be `MetaM (List MVarId)`?

Possibly also `tacs` should be a `MVarId \to MetaM (List MVarId)`?

Does this make sense? My objections are:
* This is all operating in `MetaM` anyway, using `run`. (maybe TermElabM, whatever)
* TacticM shouldn't ever be returning `List MVarId`: that's what its state is for!
* I want a purely `MetaM` level version of all this anyway.

You're right! Looking back I actually don't know why I even defined `runAndFailIfNoProgress`. I replaced it with `MVarId.failIfNoProgress`, `MVarId.failIfNoProgress'`, and `MVarId.failIfNoProgress1` in analogy to the corresponding `liftMetaTactic`s, all in `MetaM`.

```suggestion
Config data for `failIfNoProgress`, `fail_if_no_progress`, and `runAndFailIfNoProgress`. This
```
On first reading I found this confusing, because I didn't already at my finger tips the difference between these. Maybe just ordering them as `fail_if_no_progress`, `failIfNoProgress` and `runAndFailIfNoProgress` would be helpful. Or better a parenthesis: "`fail_if_no_progress` (the user facing tactic), `failIfNoProgress` (in `TacticM`)".

I'm not going to insist, but it seems the ratio of configuration options to tests is high! We could add more exhaustive tests, or perhaps just try next time to resist the temptation to add so many knobs that we can't even be bothered testing them. :-)

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion | .beq => true ```
I'm surprised this is part of the linter. There's currently an RFC about this: leanprover/lean4#2580.
I'm not sure the RFC has much traction. :-)

pullRequest.title: feat: config options for `fail_if_no_progress`
